title: Gravitational field - explain constant value of g

content.question: Why can the gravitational field strength <math alttext="lowercase g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> near Earth’s surface be approximated as constant?

choices.label: Because <math alttext="lowercase g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> is a fundamental constant of nature and has the same value everywhere.
Because the field strength is proportional to the universal gravitational constant, <math alttext="uppercase G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>G</mi></math>.
Because distance scales near Earth’s surface are very small compared to Earth’s radius.

content.answer: Because distance scales near Earth’s surface are very small compared to Earth’s radius.
